case_vignette: A 56-year-old man comes to the phys   ician because of a 2-month history of worsening pain in his left buttock. The pain is described as a deep, dull ache that is    worse at    night. He does not report any recent  trauma. He has hy   perlipidemia. He has smoked one pack of  cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and drinks one beer every night. He does not use i   llicit drugs. His only medication is simvastat in. Physical examination shows tenderness over the left gluteal region. Neurologic examination shows no f   ocal   findings. An x-ray of the pelvis shows a 4-cm   , poorly defined, osteolytic lesion in the   left ilium with a moth-eaten pattern of bone destruct   ion, mult  iple well-defined sclerotic lesions, and an aggressive pe   r iosteal reaction. The remainder of the physical examination, including rectal examination, shows no abnormalities. Chest x -ray and abdominal ultrasonograph   y show no abno  rmalities.
question: Which  is the most li   kely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing a worsening deep, dull ache in my left buttock for the past two months, and it gets worse at night.
Do you have any other symptoms like weight loss, fever, or changes in bowel or bladder habits?
No, I don't have any of those symptoms.
Have you noticed any skin changes or nodules around the area where you feel pain?
No, I haven't noticed any skin changes or nodules around the painful area.
Have you had any recent injuries or do you often engage in activities that strain your lower back or buttocks?
No, I have not had any recent injuries or engaged in activities that strain my lower back or buttocks.
Do you have any history of cancer, or is there a family history of cancer?
No, I do not have any personal or family history of cancer.
Have you tried any treatments or medications for your pain so far? If yes, what were they and did they provide any relief?
I'm only taking simvastatin and haven't tried any specific treatments or medications for this pain yet.
Has any imaging or diagnostic testing, like an MRI or X-ray, been done for your buttock pain? If so, what were the results?

Yes, an x-ray of my pelvis was done which showed a 4-cm osteolytic lesion in the left ilium with a moth-eaten pattern of bone destruction, multiple well-defined sclerotic lesions, and an aggressive periosteal reaction.
**Final Diagnosis:** Metastatic bone disease
